docs.abstract: In Minneapolis, where George Floyd was killed, educators have used the trial as an opportunity to help their students examine the complex issues of race, policing and the criminal justice system.
docs.snippet: In Minneapolis, where George Floyd was killed, educators have used the trial as an opportunity to help their students examine the complex issues of race, policing and the criminal justice system.
docs.lead_paragraph: At this point in the school year, Lacrissha Walton typically focuses her social studies lessons on the 50 U.S. states and their capitals. But last week, the Minneapolis teacher scrawled a question that had nothing to do with geography on her fourth-grade classroom’s whiteboard: “Have you watched the Derek Chauvin trial?”

headline.main: How Teachers Are Exploring the Derek Chauvin Trial With Students
headline.print_headline: In Minneapolis, Educators Are Bringing the Chauvin Trial Into the Classroom

docs.abstract: Natalie T. Chase, a District Court judge in Arapahoe County, agreed to step down after the Colorado Supreme Court censured her for insensitive remarks to Black judicial employees.
docs.snippet: Natalie T. Chase, a District Court judge in Arapahoe County, agreed to step down after the Colorado Supreme Court censured her for insensitive remarks to Black judicial employees.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Colorado judge has agreed to resign after the state Supreme Court censured her for repeatedly using a racial slur and making insensitive comments to Black judicial employees regarding police brutality and systemic racism.

headline.main: Colorado Judge Will Resign After Using Racial Slur, Court Says

docs.abstract: “It’s hard to celebrate, because a man is still dead, but there is a sense of relief that at least this one injustice was not compounded with indifference,” said a somber Stephen Colbert.
docs.snippet: “It’s hard to celebrate, because a man is still dead, but there is a sense of relief that at least this one injustice was not compounded with indifference,” said a somber Stephen Colbert.
docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline.main: Late Night Addresses the Derek Chauvin Verdict

docs.abstract: If they really wanted to help the working class, there is plenty they could do.
docs.snippet: If they really wanted to help the working class, there is plenty they could do.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican Party may not have much of an agenda to sell to the public right now, but it does have an enemy with which to rally its troops: “woke capital,” or those corporations that have adopted progressive rhetoric on social issues and used their platforms to support voting rights or back movements like Black Lives Matter.

docs.abstract: The aftermath of the George Floyd protests and a decreased reliance on standardized tests have led to more diverse admissions at elite universities.
docs.snippet: The aftermath of the George Floyd protests and a decreased reliance on standardized tests have led to more diverse admissions at elite universities.
docs.lead_paragraph: Jianna Curbelo attends a career-focused public high school in New York City, works at McDonald’s and lives in the Bronx with her unemployed mother, who did not graduate from college.

headline.main: After a Year of Turmoil, Elite Universities Welcome More Diverse Freshman Classes

docs.abstract: Mr. Scott leaned heavily on his extraordinary biography to argue against Mr. Biden’s infrastructure plan.
docs.snippet: Mr. Scott leaned heavily on his extraordinary biography to argue against Mr. Biden’s infrastructure plan.
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina on Wednesday night dismissed President Biden’s latest ambitious economic package and accused him of abandoning his pledge to work with Republicans, advancing instead a divisive and partisan agenda.

headline.main: Tim Scott, delivering the G.O.P. rebuttal, accuses Biden of abandoning bipartisanship.

byline.original: By Catie Edmondson and Zach Montague

docs.abstract: The family of Tamir Rice, a 12-year-old boy who was shot and killed in 2014 by the Cleveland police, has asked Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to reopen the Justice Department’s investigation into the shooting.
